message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms such as fatigue, muscle weakness, and thick calves, together with the elevated CPK and LDH levels suggest the most likely condition is Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is caused by a nonsense mutation in the DMD gene. β-thalassemia does not present with these symptoms. The WT gene is associated with Wilms tumor, not muscle weakness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the thick calves, waddling gait, and elevated CPK and LDH levels suggest that the most likely cause is Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). This is caused by a nonsense mutation in the DMD gene, resulting in a defective or absent dystrophin protein. The other options are not associated with these symptoms or lab findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a form of muscular dystrophy, and the thick calves and difficulty standing up from a sitting position indicate Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Elevated CPK and LDH levels confirm muscle damage. Nonsense mutations in the DMD gene are the most common cause of DMD. Missense mutations in the β-thalassemia gene would not cause these symptoms, nor would a mutation in the WT gene.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including fatigue, waddling gait, and difficulty rising from a seated position, suggest muscle weakness, which is typical of Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD). The thickened calves and elevated CPK and LDH levels are also consistent with DMD. Option A, missense mutation in β-thalassemia gene, is unrelated to the symptoms. Option D, mutation in WT gene, is too vague and does not provide any useful information.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of muscle weakness, thickened calves, and elevated CPK and LDH suggest a muscular dystrophy. Among the options, only missense and nonsense mutations in the DMD gene are associated with muscular dystrophy, specifically Duchenne muscular dystrophy which presents in childhood with progressive muscle weakness. The fact that there is a family history of similar symptoms also supports this diagnosis. The missense mutation in β-thalassemia gene is associated with a blood disorder and the mutation in the WT gene is associated with Wilms tumor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest a muscle weakness disorder, and the elevated CPK and LDH indicate muscle damage. Thick calves are a common finding in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), which is caused by a mutation in the DMD gene. Missense mutations in the DMD gene are a common cause of DMD, whereas nonsense mutations are less common. β-thalassemia and the WT gene are not associated with muscle weakness and elevated CPK and LDH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), which is caused by mutations in the DMD gene. Elevated CPK and LDH levels are also seen in DMD. β-thalassemia and WT mutations are not associated with these symptoms. A missense mutation in the DMD gene is the most likely cause as it is the most common type of mutation in DMD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of fatigue, difficulty getting up from a chair, and waddling gait, along with thick calves and elevated CPK and LDH suggest a diagnosis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). DMD is caused by a mutation in the DMD gene, specifically a nonsense mutation that results in a truncated or absent dystrophin protein. β-Thalassemia is a genetic disorder that affects hemoglobin production and would not cause muscle weakness, and mutations in the WT gene are associated with Wilms tumor, a type of kidney cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of waddling gait, difficulty standing from a sitting position, lethargy, and thick calves suggest that the patient has Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Elevated CPK and LDH levels also support this diagnosis. DMD is caused by mutations in the DMD gene, with a nonsense mutation resulting in a severe form of the disease. Missense mutations in β-thalassemia or DMD genes, as well as mutations in the WT gene, would not be consistent with the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of fatigue, difficulty getting out of a seat, waddling gait, and thick calves suggest muscular dystrophy. The elevated levels of CPK and LDH also support this diagnosis. Among the options, only missense and nonsense mutations in the DMD gene are associated with muscular dystrophy. Beta-thalassemia and WT mutations are not associated with these symptoms.
